summary: viral respiratory tract infections are a common cause of hospitalization and mortality in infants and young children. there is a need for a rapid and sensitive differential diagnosis of respiratory viral pathogens to prevent nosocomial infections and to minimize unnecessary antibiotic usage [4–6]. influenza A virus (FluA), influenza B virus (FluB), seasonal influenza A virus subtypes H1N1 (sH1N1), parainfluenza virus type 1 (PIV1), human rhinovirus (HRV), coronavirus subtypes 229E (CoV 229E), and adenovirus (Adv) another tube is used for the simultaneous detection of seven respiratory viruses including parainfluenza virus type 2 (PIV2), parainfluenza 149 participants were male and 98 (39.68%) female. the specimens were collected within 5 to 7 days after symptoms onset. children's parents were informed of the study's purpose. Plasmid Mini Kit I. the sensitivity of the two-tube assay was examined by using premixed quantitative viral RNA transcripts. additional targets detected only by the Luminex xTAG RVP Fast assay were resolved using remaining extracts with the Seeplex RV15 ACE detection kit. results 3.1. Specificity and Sensitivity of the two-tube assay. all positive controls were identified successfully, and no mispriming was observed in either tube. Lanes 11–17 show the results of amplification of RSVA (163 bp), coV NL63 (179 b), PIV2 (198 bp), PIV3 (233 bp), RSVB (280 bp), and HBoV (298 bp) detection sensitivity in tube 1 with 9 pre-mixed viral targets was 2000 copies per reaction and 200 copies per reaction in tube 2 with 7 premixed templates. Lanes 7 to 11 contain PCR products of pre-mixed viral targets in tube 1 of 2 106 to 200 copies. only the amplicons of sH1N1 and CoV 229E were absent. the Luminex xTAG RVP RVP Fast assay identified 111 specimens to be coinfections, 83 of them were in complete agreement between both assays. additional 14 viruses were detected only by the two-tube assay, and 2 coinfection specimens gave inconsistent results between the two assays. 3, HBoV, and HEV/HRV PIV3, RSVB, PIV3, and HBoV 270 PIV3, RSVB, and HMPV PIV3, RSVB, and HMPV 142 RSVB RSVB, and HEV/HRV PIV3, RSVB, and HMPV 142 RSVB RSVB, and HEV/HRV PIV3, RSVB, and HMPV 142 RSVB RSVB, and dND stands for not detected. 40 viral infections identified only by the two-tube assay. 21 viral infections found only by the Luminex xTAG RVP Fast assay. two-tube/Luminex xTAG RVP Fast assay Performance of the two-tube assay compared with the Luminex xTAG RVP Fast assay +/+ +/ /+ / Sensitivity% Specificity% PPV% NPV% Accordance rate% Kappa FluA. sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV) and the kappa values for each target were shown using the Luminex xTAG RVP RVP Fast assay as the reference for comparison. all the kappa values were above 0.75, indicating that the two assays were in agreement. 100 100 100 100 1.000 PIV3 24 0 0 223 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 HRV 110 0 3 134 97.35 100 100 97.81 98.79 0.975 HMPV 28 0 0 219 100 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 Adv 35 0 1 211 97.22 100 100 99.53 99.60 0.984 CoV NL63 1 0 0 246 100 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 CoV 229 all positive controls were identified successfully, and no mispriming was observed in either tube. HBoV 28 0 5 214 84.85 100 100 100 97.72 97.98 0.907 The numbers of positive and negative specimens detected by both testing methods are shown. the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV) and the kappa values for each target were above 0.75, indicating that the two assays were in agreement. 100 100 1.000 PIV1 1 0 0 246 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 PIV2 2 0 0 245 100 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 PIV3 24 0 0 223 100 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 HRV 110 0 3 134 97.35 100 100 97.81 98.79 0.975 HMPV 28 0 0 219 100 100 100 100 100 100 1.000 Adv 35 0 1 211 97.22 100 247 specimens from hospitalized children showed a high prevalence of infection and co-infection with the common respiratory viral pathogens. the major discrepancies between the two-tube assay introduced in this study and the Luminex xTAG RVP RVP Fast assay were found for the detection of HRV, Adv, HBoV, RSVB, and sH1N1. the detection results of coronaviruses (CoV HKU1, CoV NL63, CoV 229E, and CoV OC43), influenza (FluA, FluB), PIV1 and PIV2 were completely consistent between the two assays. no false positives were found by the two-tube assay, and a total of 6 false negatives occurred. the clinical relevance of multiplex PCR tests for respiratory viruses is not yet fully determined. in one study of children with RSV infection, higher fever, longer hospital stays, and more frequent use of antibiotics were associated with multiple infections. a rapid etiologic diagnosis of viral RTI could reduce unnecessary prescription of antibiotics.
